title: discover-hidden-gems-dotted-throughout-dumfries
story: --------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Annan Harbour FestivalAnnan Harbour Festival on th August celebrates the Solway Firth and Annan Harbourrsquos pivotal role in connecting people with their unique coastal environment and maritime heritage. This year there is a focus on food and drink heritage and culture offering an interesting and fun day out for everyone."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Annan Harbour","description": "Annan Harbour","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs rexlUr-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests rexlUr.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The food anddrink theme focusses on the burgeoning community of local producers with more than  exhibitors occupying an all-weather facility to showcase their products. Food theatre will be a highlight with cookery demonstrations by chefs and young cooks, compared by Cat Frankitti, the well-known and highly respected champion of fish and seafood, who is guaranteed to present a lively and interesting show.Celebrating Annanrsquos heritage and the crafts long associated with the townrsquos maritime past will also feature, along with the environmental riches of our river and coastline. These will be brought to le through displays and there will be hands-on activities for every member of the family. The centre piece being a special exhibition on haaf netting, the -year old Viking method of catching salmon in shallow fast flowing water.Annan Harbour Festival is a free day out with plenty of family fun and entertainment, the organisers Annan Harbour Action Group are community activists who are leading the regeneration of the former trading, emigration and fishing port, to restore it as an economic driver for the town, a water sports venue and a community events space.To find out more, visit the Facebook page.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Kailzie GardensKailzie Gardens, located only two and a half miles from Peebles town centre, is a picture-perfect spot to visit year-round. Showcasing a rich iety of colour and charm whatever the season, the gardens provide an idyllic place to wander around for both keen gardeners and those who simply wish to appreciate the natural beauty.The Wild Garden is at its best in the spring when Snowdrops are followed by massed Daffodils and Bluebells, providing a magnicent carpet of colour. Meanwhile in the Walled Garden, there are many shrubs and roses to marvel at, including Rosa Albas, Celestial and Great Maidens Blush, Rosa Centolia and Fantin Latour.Birdwatchers will also find much to see here. As Kailzie Gardens is a major partner in the successful Tweed Valley Osprey Project, there is the chance to spot one of these rare and beautul birds. The project has encouraged and protected more of these specialist fish hunting raptors into the quiet forests, lochs and rivers nearby."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Kailzie Gardens","description": "Kailzie Gardens","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs erunlTZQ-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests erunlTZQ.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": After a day spent wandering the gardens and spotting birds, Kailzie Courtyard Cafeacute is the ideal place to rest and refuel. Situated in the old stable square, the cafeacute has a cosy charm having retained many of the original features. Open seven days a week from am ndash .pm, visitors can enjoy hot and cold drinks and snacks.With beauty galore all year round, Kailzie Gardens has become a popular destination for weddings, both for religious and civil ceremonies. Offering a glorious location to tie the knot, they also provide flexibility in conjunction with the restaurant to host any size of gathering, able to accommodate the smallest or the largest of marquees. The chef can sit with couples and help organise a tasting of dishes and some of the finer details.For visitors coming from further afield planning a short break in the Scottish Borders, Kailzie Gardens can provide accommodation via their self-catering cottage, which sleeps six, and bunkhouse sleeping up to  people.To find out more about visiting the gardens or planning a wedding, visitwww.kailziegardensor call   .--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------The Devilrsquos Porridge MuseumThe Devilrsquos Porridge Museum is a  star, award winning museum.Located in Dumfries and Galloway, it tells the story of the greatest munitions factory in World War One.It spanned an area nine-miles long and two-miles wide and contained a state of the art factory along with  miles of railway track,  stations, two towns, a power station, two cinemas, hospitals, a dentists, a maternity unit and schools., people worked here, , of them women.They mixed the devilrsquos porridge, which is a nickname for cordite, a propellant which was included within every single bullet and shell used in the First World War One.More than half of all the cordite used by the British armed forces was produced at this Anglo-Scottish site.People came from around the Empire to add their expertise: South African explosives experts, Australian chemists and Canadian engineers.They left their mark on the local area in the street names of Eastriggssuch as Vancouver Avenue and Delhi Road.This had led to Eastriggs being known as lsquothe Commonwealth village.rsquoThe Gretna girls had a dficult le: they worked with chemicals which caused their teeth to fall out, which discoloured their skin and caused them to feint from the fumes. Some young women suffered worse fates: an explosion killed one local girl, others lost arms and fingers or were severely burned due to the fires which could break out. Their work and leisure lives were strictly monitored: everything came under the official secrets act and over  members of the Womenrsquos Police Service monitored their movements and morals!The museum is set across two floors with interactive displays including films, games and oral testimonies of people from World War One and Two. There is so much military history in this part of Scotland that it has been named lsquoThe Solway Military Coastrsquo and the upstairs in the museum the story continues into World War Two in this region and even includes a look at the start of the Cold War with a virtual reality headset experience to explore inside Chapelcross, Scotlandrsquos first nuclear power station.The Devilrsquos Porridge Museum regularly tops Dumfries and Gallowayrsquos things to do on Tripadvisor and has recently been shortlisted for the prestigious lsquoMost Family Friendly Museum in the UK Award.rsquoVisit the website, Facebook, Twitteror Instagram.-------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------Philiphaugh EstateSituated just to the North and West of the Royal Burgh of Selkirk lies Philiphaugh Estate, perhaps best known for the Civil War battle fought between the Marquis of Montrose for the Royalistsand General Leslie of the Covenanterson  September . Montrose with inferior forces was outflanked by the Covenanters and suffered total defeat thus ending the Royalist cause in Scotland.Today there is a battlefield walk from Selkirk to the Waterwheel Cafeacute , parallel to the A, Selkirk-Moffat road. Signboards describing the combatants and explaining how the battle unfolded are placed along the field where musket balls, lead shot and belt buckles have been recovered."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Philiphaugh Salmon Viewing Centre","description": "Philiphaugh Salmon Viewing Centre","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs AXuFsKY-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests AXuFsKY.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The Waterwheel Cafeacuteprovides good value meals, tea coffee and delicious home baking. There is a car park and childrenrsquos play area. The cafeacute overlooks the ground where Montrose cut his way through the melee of soldiers to escape up the Yarrow Valley and over the Minchmoor to safety.Close by you may visit the Salmon Viewing Centre, housed in an old threshing mill. You will learn of the amazing le cycle of the Atlantic salmon. Ideal for children with a tunnel representing the riverbed, to crawl through and emerge as salmon fry! There is a computer game about the journey the salmon makes when ing to the river to spawn.An underwater camera can be selected by pressing a button on the display  and you may see fish live on the main screen. If you fail to spot anything there are recorded highlights showing salmon and sea trout and other creatures underwater. In addition, there are video clips of the major native wildle species in Scotland.There is also a working model of an Archimedes Screw turbine, which enables visitors to appreciate the workings of the Hydro station where two massive  tons Archimedes Screw Turbines are situated on the River Ettrick and generate electricity. In a year some , kwh are generated, which is enough electricity to power  houses. Salmon may be seen jumping at the cauld in high water.Pick up a pamphlet in the cafeacute or at the Salmon Viewing Centre and you will find a map showing walks: the longest leads to Harehead Hill,  feet with magnicent views to the Ettrick and Yarrow valleys and to the Cheviot and Eildon Hills. Visitors can also see the old Victorian Walled Garden where fresh fruit, vegetables, cut flowers and bedding plants may be purchased.A new attraction is a craft gin distillery. Selkirk Distillers make a delicious lsquoReiverrsquo gin and lsquoBannockrsquo gin from the internationally famous Selkirk bannock. The distillery and gardens can be accessed either by car or on foot.Set in the beautul Borders landscapewith field and woodlands carefully designed with the land form, a visit to Philiphaugh Estate will be memorable for the beauty of the countryside and the many visitor attractions grouped around the cafeacute, Hydro Station and Salmon Viewing Centre.Visitwww.salmonviewingcentreto find out more.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------CatStrandCatStrand is an award-winning arts and visitor centre in New Galloway, Scotlandrsquos smallest Royal Burgh. Ideally located within the Galloway andSouth Ayrshire Biosphere Reserve and adjacent to Galloway Forest Park and Europersquos first designated Dark Sky Park, a visit to CatStrand is a must.The cafeacute, shop and gallery are open sevendays throughout the year, selling local produce and showcasing the work of local artists and makers. A high quality programme of music,theatre, cinema, comedy, dance and visual arts is also presented in the CatStrandrsquos own auditorium and in partnership with other local venues. The popular venue has hosted many famous performers from Scotland and throughout the world such as Ricky Ross, Kiki Dee, Fred MacAulay, Judie Tzuke, Kris Drever, Ross Noble and Juan Martin.The wonderfully adaptable and fully accessible facilities are available for hire and are perfect for meetings, conferences, exhibitions, rehearsal space and celebrations.Visit Scotland awarded CatStrand  Star Arts Venue status in  and the staff are always happy to help visitors to get the very best out of this beautul corner of Scotland with local information and advice.For more information visitwww.catstrand, call  or email info@catstrand.Regular opening hours: Monday to Friday am - pm, Saturdays am-pm, Sundays am - pm.--------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------TraquairTraquair is Scotlandrsquos oldest, continually inhabited house set amidst the beautul rolling hills of the Scottish Borders. Its history spans over  years from when it was originally built as a hunting lodge for the kings and queens of Scotland. Amongst the animals they hunted were bears, which are now a strong emblem at Traquair.Traquair also played host to Mary Queen of Scots in  when she visited with her husband Darnley. Traquair still has the bed where she slept and the cradle where she rocked her baby, later James V of Scotland and I England."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Traquair House","description": "Traquair House","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs ebYSWHp-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests ebYSWHp.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": The Stuarts of Traquair have been in residence since  and the house remains a family home today. They were strong Catholics and Jacobites and maintained a constant loyalty to the Stuart monarchs without counting the cost. In  Bonnie Prince Charlie visited Traquair and as he left the house the Earl of Traquair closed the famous Bear Gates at the top of the avenue, promising they would remain closed until a Stuart ed to the throne. They remain closed to this day.As Catholics the family would have to practise in secret and at the top of the house a small Priestrsquos Room can be found with a secret staircase hidden behind a bookcase that could be used for a speedy escapea raid took place.In one of the wings of the house lying under the Chapel is a brew house which is now producing the world famous Traquair House Ales. Built in the rsquos to service the family and the estate it was disused in the early rsquos and lay dormant as the family junk room until it was rediscovered in the mid rsquos by the th Laird, Peter Maxwell Stuart. He started brewing again in  and beers continued to be brewed here using the original equipment, fermented in the ancient oak tuns and are exported worldwide. There is also, of course the chance to try them when you visit.As well as the house and the brewery Traquair also boasts the largest hedged maze in Scotland. Get lostyou dare!The grounds which stretch down to the River Tweed contain some stunning ancient woodlands. You can also explore four craft workshops contained in some of the old outbuildings including jewellery and leatherwork, pottery, drtwood sculpture and a range of hand made personalised fabrics.In the Old Walled Garden there is a lovely Cafeacute in the  Cottage which has won plaudits for its superb range of home baking, light lunches and snacks.The house is open to the public every day during the summer months from am ndash pm and in July and August from am ndash pm and also offers accommodation in three luxurious rooms on a bed and breakfast basis.

title: Rosemary Goring  Scotland s history has lain in the British shadow for too long
story: It needed more than grouting, as I now realise. In recent weeks, for background to a book Irsquom writing about Mary Queen of Scots ndash donrsquot yawn! ndash Irsquove been visiting some of the locations of her troubled years here. Despite a lelong interest in history, doubtless in part due to early brainwashing, I have been shamed to discover how much of the past there is, within easy reach, that Irsquove never bothered to seek out or explore.When it comes to ill-fated Mary, Historic Environment Scotland offers a guide to most of the key points in her tale, as found in old buildings and sites. Itrsquos a clever idea, pandering to an international fascination with her that never fades. Of all our prominent figures, not even Charles Edward Stuart has the abiding allure of this deeply tragic royal. Hence the number of visitors from Japan and America in Linlithgow Palace, where she was born, or the Germans photographing forbidding Hermitage Castle in the Borders, where she paid a fleeting visit to the wounded Earl of Bothwell, a trip that cost her dear.Yet what is immediately obvious is how few locals there are clambering up Dumbarton Rock, where she stayed for months as a child, before being whisked to safety in France, or on the woodland paths around the site of the Battle of Carberry Hill, where her fate was effectively sealed.Arguably the most important location, Dundrennan Abbey in Dumfries  Galloway, had no other visitors whatsoever while I was there at the weekend. It hardly appears to be on anyonersquos radar, even though in terms of Mary it is hugely symbolic, being the very last place she slept before leaving for England. When her boat reached Cumbria, from the tiny nearby port, she was to spend the rest of her le in captivity. There is far more to Dundrennan, however, than the memory of Maryrsquos passing. A tranquil haven, in lush countryside close to the sea, this th-century Cistercian abbey survived the wars of independence, though not the tumult of the Reformation. Above all, it is architecturally fascinating, showing the arrival of the gothic style in Scotland.The enchanting narrow and winding roads around here, and for that matter all across this un-sung region, were almost car free. Yoursquore more likely to encounter a milk tanker than a motorcycle. Put a grandfather clock in our back seat, and we could have been on The Antiques Roadshow, tootling through bucolic pastoral scenery, one foot firmly planted in yesteryear.The richness of history that lies all around us is staggering. Yet, either because of over-familiarity, complacency or lack of knowledge, it is half-forgotten or ignored. Even our glitziest period celebrity cannot draw crowds much beyond the central belt. Scotlandrsquos bygone affairs, you might say, do not have the magnetic pull of British history ndash ie, English ndash in whose shadow they have lain for as long as time has been measured.Population density and accessibility in part explain why English monuments and castles are crawling with tourists, whereas the wind whistles emptily through many of ours. Stonehenge, just off a convenient main road, attracts millions, whereas to visit the far eerier Callanish Stones on the isle of Lewis requires determination and planning. Nor could the ferry cope with a sudden surge in traffic.But therersquos more to it than that. Until fairly recently, our history was seen by those who shaped the curriculum, and the political agenda, as a branch of a bigger tree. Despite the profoundly influential impact of our royal dynasties across all these isles, and our complex, sophisticated political system, even today most of us are still probably better versed in Tudor kings and queens than in the equally colourful Stuarts.While we live in more enlightened times now, connecting with our past is as much our own responsibility as that of the educational or cultural establishment. Who cares whether British history gets more attention than Scottish, Welsh or Irish  The abundance of clues left by our forebears is a priceless record, a heritage written plain and loud as a redtop headline. We donrsquot need permission, or a professional go-between, to discover it for ourselves.School teachers are well aware that facts and dates rarely stick without something to bring them alive. Visit Scotland, and the past rises to meet you at every turn. Some of it lies beneath our feet, the bones of early civilisation, or the work of long-gone farmers, still visible ason an x-ray. Castles, forts, mines and harbours are all within easy reach of most of us. As scaremongers like to say of rats, yoursquore never more than a few feet from a fragment of history anywhere in this land.Indeed, therersquos so much of it you can understand why some people feel oppressed, fearing that to pay our national saga too much attention will hold us back. For me, though, the wealth of evidence is invigorating. Following in the footsteps of a figure such as Mary Queen of Scots is to feel an almost tangible connection. Rather than highlighting how far distant were the times in which she lived, it has the opposite effect. Listening to crows cawing on the rooftop of Linlithgow Palace, or the kittiwakes nesting on the ruins of Dunbar Castle looking out across Arthurrsquos Seat from Craigmillar Castle, or to the English coast from the beach near Dundrennan, is actually to sense that those who shaped our country were in most important respects not much dferent from us.As Irsquom belatedly learning, jaunts to castles and battle sites are a three-dimensional holiday, offering a perspective that reaches deep into the archives. Rather than encouraging nostalgia or sentiment, it is instead a bracing reminder of the urgent need to live in the here and now. Therersquos nothing like a ruin to show you how quickly time catches us all.

title: snp-mavericks-try-revive-independence-39-plan-b-39
story: Western Isles MP Angus Brendan MacNeil and Inverclyde councillor Chris McEleny said a ldquoPlan B was neededthe new PM blocks a second referendum.Their idea is thatMr Johnson refuses to grant Holyrood the power to hold a vote using a Section  order, a simple election win would be used as a mandate for ending the Union.If pro-independence SNP and Green candidates won a majority of seats at the next Westminster or Holyrood election, it would trigger independence negotiations.The Scottish Tories accused them of droning on "like golfclub bores".:SNP mavericks suggest a new route to independenceThe idea flies in the face of Nicola Sturgeonrsquos repeated insistence that the legally-binding referendum process of  is the ldquogold standard and only template for Indyref.PM Boris makes myself an @SNPChris take Independence Plan B back to SNP conference as an amendment - we need the independence volume turned up! #indyref #hope https:t.co oGdhZJbQThe First Minister has said she wants to hold another referendum in late , but has so far failed to say what she would dothe PM refused to grant a Section  order.Theresa May simply stonewalled a previous request from MSPs in .With parts of the Yes movement impatient for action, and worried about another refusal, Mr MacNeil and Mr McEleny tried to get their idea debated at the SNPrsquos autumn conference.However their motion was rejected by the SNP leadership, with national secretary Angus MacLeod dismissing the idea as ldquohastily written, almost whimsically so.Mr MacLeod also said it was ldquowholly inappropriate for the pair to brief the media about it.Mr MacNeil said he was ldquoutterly stumped by the decision earlier this month.:SNP MP utterly stumped by partys refusal to debate independence planHowever he and Mr McEleny now want to resurrect the idea by amending an uncontroversial motion about  years of Holyrood to get the subject debated and voted on by delegates.They are urging SNP activists to email Mr MacLeod to add their names to their amendment, which would instruct the SNP to put the Plan B idea into its next manesto.The text of their amendment says: ldquoThe manesto for the next Scottish or UK Parliamentary election ndash whichever may come first ndash shall state that, a pro independence electoral victory shall be a mandate from the people of Scotland to commence independence negotiations with the UK Government.Mr MacNeil said: ldquoAll Scotland is aghast at the latest choice being foisted on our country.ldquoClearly Boris and his party are not Scotlandrsquos choice and havenrsquot been for over six decades, and we can see from our independent Nordic and Irish neighbours that there is a better way.ldquoScotland has a mandate for a referendum on independence and Westminster must respect this. If it doesnrsquot, then we must ensure that the Scottish Government, on behalf of the people, has another club in its bag to influence negotiations over a Section  order.ldquoNamely we need the prospect of a direct mandate for independence from a majority of MPs from a Westminster Electionto positively progress Scotland to the prosperity of our Nordic and Irish neighbours and away from the damaging policies of Westminster.:Neil Mackay: Why the Plan B path to independence reveals a world of pain for the SNPCllr McEleny, who represents ordinary party members on the SNPrsquos ruling national executive, added: ldquoSNP members and the independence movement were not happy when our motion was rejected without even allowing a debate.With Boris Johnson now PM, myself and @AngusMacNeilSNP have the proposed Indy plan B as an amendment at @theSNP conference.Agree to a Section  order @BorisJohnson or we will ensure Scotlandrsquos voice is heard another wayneed be. https:t.co AZJqTPVMldquoNow we will have the opportunity to recognise all we have achieved thanks to the Scottish Parliament but importantly put in place a plan B to give our Parliament all the powers of an ordinary independent countrythe UK Government refuse to agree to Section  order.Tory MSP Annie Wells said: "Senior figures in the SNP are now resembling golf club bores with their relentless and predictable calls for another independence referendum.ldquoTheyrsquore droning on repeatedly to anyone within earshot about the break-up of Britain, when most voters want Scotland to move on from constitutional mayhem.ldquoNicola Sturgeon should be using the arrival of a new Prime Minister as a way of helping Scotland thrive within the UK.ldquoInstead, shersquos being her opportunistic self and banging the drum for another unwanted and isive referendum.ldquoThat would only set Scotland back even further, and spoil any chance we have of boosting jobs, prosperity and public services for the future.Pamela Nash, chief executive of the anti-independence Scotland in Union campaign, said:ldquoThis is utter desperation from these senior SNP politicians.ldquoScotland voted against independence in a referendum we were promised was once-in-a-letime. Trying to get independence through the back door would be simply unacceptable for the people of Scotland.ldquoToday the steep challenges, including tax rises and public service cuts, that Scotland would facewe broke away from the rest of the UK are exactly the same as they were yesterday.ldquoWhatever your views on Boris Johnson, the very last thing Scotland needs is another isive independence referendum and more constitutional chaos.ldquoNicola Sturgeon has already had to rule out this irresponsible plan, but this challenge to her authority means she must now do so again.An SNP spokeswoman said: "The process of producing the agenda is the internal business of the Scottish National Party, with motions shortlisted by a democratically elected internal body."The SNP already has a cast-iron mandate for holding an independence referendum before the  election, and the First Minister has made clear that she believes this should take place in the second half of next year."

title: may-flip-flopped-no-deal-brexit-union-says-top-aide
story: Gavin Barwell said Mrs May, who famously proclaimed ldquono-deal is better than a bad deal, changed her mind after visiting Northern Ireland.He said she had been concerned about the combined effect of aof a hard border with the Republic of Ireland and the lack of stable government in the North.:SNP say Ruth Davidson lsquohumiliatedrsquo after David Mundell sacked against her adviceThe devolved power-sharing executive and assembly collapsed in January  after disagreements between the DUP and Sinn Fein.Mrs May included a coded warning against no-deal in her farewell speech in Downing Street yesterday, calling for a Brexit that ldquoworks for the whole of the United Kingdom."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Theresa May gives her final speech as PM","description": "Theresa May gives her final speech as PM","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs CeWCODV-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests CeWCODV.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Mr Barwell, a former Tory MP, told BBC Radio rsquos Today programme that Mrs May was worried a no-deal Brexit could drive support for Irish unication.He said: ldquoShe is a passionate unionist and she has spent a signicant amount of time in Northern Ireland during her premiership.ldquoAnd every time she visited, that, sort of, sense that the combination of Brexit and what it could mean to the border between Northern Ireland and Ireland and the lack of devolved government in Northern Ireland that there was a real threat.ldquoThe Secretary of State for Northern Ireland is on a statutory duty to call a border pollshe believes there is evidence to support one. So, that is a real concern to her, yes.Mrs May was also warned about the impact of a no-deal by her Scottish Secretary David Mundell, who identied it as potential fuel for the Scottish independence movement.Both Northern Ireland and Scotland voted Remain in the  EU referendum.Earlier this month, Mr Mundell wrote in a newspaper that First Minister Nicola Sturgeon would seize on a disorderly Brexit ldquowith unseemly glee.:Boris Johnson holding first cabinet meetingHe said: ldquoA dficult no-deal Brexit would not only damage our economy, it would fuel nationalist claims of a UK that is insensitive to Scotlandrsquos needs.ldquoThe new prime minister faces considerable challenges, and the future of the UK is high on the list.With Boris Johnson saying he is ready to embrace no-deal in order to achieve Brexit by October  - a point he made again in his first Downing Street address as Prime Minister - the SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford told Radio : ldquoI think as it stands today he could be the last prime minister of the United Kingdom.

title: oh-conservative-voters-done-uk
story: The tradition began in earnest when one Margaret Hilda Thatcher rocked up to Downing Street on May , , quoting St Francis of Assisi: lsquoWhere there is discord, may we bring harmony. Where there is error, may we bring truth. Where there is doubt, may we bring faith. And where there is despair, may we bring hope.: Call an election nowI remember it well. Some people have their moon landing memories, others recall where they were on hearing of the the deaths of JFK Elvis Diana. I was watching the news in a friendrsquos house when Margaret Thatcher arrived in Downing Street. The summation by my friendrsquos mother, though it seemed bleak at the time, turned out to be blisteringly accurate: ldquoWersquore in the soup now.How true. Everything Mrs Thatcher promised to do, she did the opposite, trading harmony for discord and hope for despair. She left the UK ided, traumatised, and firmly set on a course that led directly to the EU referendum and where we are now.David Cameron was just as guilty of saying one thing on entering Downing Street and doing another. ldquoI want to make sure that my government always looks after the elderly, the frail the poorest in our country, said the PM who unleashed two decades of austerity.Theresa May dedicated herself to tackling injustice. A year later Grenfell Tower was ablaze  people, some of the poorest and most vulnerable in society, dead, right there in the capital city of the fth richest country on the planet.In short, whatever a Prime Minister says on the steps of Downing Street should be taken with enough salt to grit the roads during an entire Scottish winter.: No s or buts on Brexit deliverySo it was with Mr Johnson yesterday. Speaking in a voice that was part Pathe newsreel guy part crazed chipmunk, his aggressive, up and at lsquoem delivery was that of Donald Trump in his inauguration speech. Lots of promises and spending pledges, all of them issued in a scattergun way. It was ashe was speaking to his party conference rather than a sceptical country. As for his praise for the Union, his ldquoawesome foursome phrase, straight from the campaign trail, is already sounding tired.The only surprising moment was when he pledged to take personal responsibility for delivering Brexit by October . It should not have needed saying, of course he is responsible, but that he needed to say it spoke to the doubts that even he, drunk on the fizz of his powerful new job, knows is out there. Those ldquodoubters, doomsters and gloomsters he referred to are on his side of the political ide as much as the other."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Boris Johnson becomes PM: How the day in Westminster unfolded","description": "Boris Johnson becomes PM: How the day in Westminster unfolded","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs GCrxDl-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests GCrxDl.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": : Spree of resignationsIf this was the famous Johnsonian light he had been hiding under a bushel it was hardly dazzling. But never fear, say his supporters, it will all work out in the end. This, according to the Johnson faithful, is how his premiership will play out. Essentially it is his stint as London mayor Leave campaign chief revisited. He plays the role of charismatic central figure. Around him will be packed ious Rasputins, clever chaps, perhaps even a few chapesses, who will come up with the ideas and, courtesy of their cult-like zeal, will work night and day to get them through, by any means necessary. Except bus slogans, that would be far too provocative, even for them. But expect a major marketing blitz and some wizard wheezes.Next comes the assembling of a Cabinet of all the talents. Every PM claims to have one at the start. The make up of Johnsonrsquos is meant to say, ldquoLook folks, despite what you may have read and heard, I donrsquot have racist or sexist bones in my body. Irsquom a pretty cool kind of dude with room for all, even Remainers.In reality his ministerial ranks will be full of people only too easy to dump when the going gets rough, as it surely will. Being mayor is not in the same universe as being PM, the Olympics are not Brexit. This job will require Mr Johnson to master detail as never before, to maintain his calm under pressure, and PMQs will be the least of it.Theresa Mayrsquos last PMQs yesterday was a hot and bothered affair at times, the high temperatures outside reflected in the crimson sweaty faces of MPs inside the chamber. Normally such occasions are remembered for the goodwill on display, the setting aside of political dferences in common support for democracy. But with the ious digs at her successor, and her attack on Labour leader Jeremy Corbyn ndash perhaps it was time for him to accept his time is up, she suggested generously ndash the May premiership ended as it had been conducted, largely in rancour, and stained with tears . As she left the chamber she cut a lonely figure, departing as she had governed.I donrsquot recall any such session in the past in which some MPs appeared genuinely fearful about what might be coming next. Perhaps they were rattled by the US President claiming Mr Johnson to be his Mini-Me. ldquoTheyrsquore saying Britain Trump. They call him Britain Trump, he boasted. Between Mr Trumprsquos grammar, and his daughter Ivankarsquos welcome to the next PM of the ldquoUnited Kingston, it was a bad day for advertising the value of an American private education.: May bids her farewellNor can I remember so many snipes at a PM-in-waiting, particularly from his own side. Still, I expect Mr Johnsonrsquos ldquoenergy and ldquopositivity will see him through such grumbling. So far, it has made him sound more like a yoga teacher than a PM, but each to his own.One of Mrs Mayrsquos final tasks as Prime Minister was to write a memo to her successor. Oh to read the drafts of that one. Perhaps she left the pages blank on the grounds that Mr Johnson has acted throughout the last three years, indeed his entire le, as though he is in need of no-onersquos advice and already has all the answers.We cannot wait to hear them.

title: theresa-may-predicts-female-prime-ministers-stands
story: Responding to the longest serving female MP, the Mother of the House Harriet Harman, at PMQs, Mrs May she was one of just  female Tory MPs when she was first elected in .She said: ldquoIndeed, one Labour Member of Parliament approached me to encourage me to sign a private Memberrsquos Bill list because he assumed that, as a woman, I must have been a Labour Member of Parliament.ldquoI am proud to have played my part in getting more women MPs in this House. I am sure that among the women in this House today there is a future Prime Minister - perhaps more than one.Referring to Mrs Mayrsquos first meeting with President Donald Trump, Ms Harman offered ldquoa word of sisterly advice - sometimes, you just have to be a bit more careful when a man wants to hold your hand.The new LibDem leader Jo Swinson told Mrs May it was ldquoinspiring for girls in her East Dunbartonshire seat to see a female First Minister of Scotland and UK Prime Minister.In a dig at Boris Johnson, she asked Mrs Mayrsquos advice for women ldquoon how to deal with those men who think they could do a better job but are not prepared to do the actual work "@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "MPs give Theresa May standing ovation following final PMQs","description": "MPs give Theresa May standing ovation following final PMQs","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs MmRaO-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests MmRaO.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": Mrs May congratulated Ms Swinson on her new position, and said she was pleased to see an MP with a Scottish seat in a UK role, underlining the Union.She said: ldquoAs I stand down, I am pleased to be able to hand the baton on to another female leader of a political party.ldquoAs I look around the Chamber, I have to say that we almost have a full set. My party has had two women leaders, the Liberal Democrats now have a woman leader, and the SNP has a woman leader, as does the DUP, Plaid and the Greens.ldquoEven the independent TIGger group, Change UK, or whatever they are calling themselves this week, are now on to their second woman leader.ldquoThere is only one party in this House letting the side down: the Labour party.

title: may-bows-parting-commons-jab-corbyn
story: After a tetchy final exchange with the Labour leader, she said: ldquoAs a party leader who has accepted when her time was up, perhaps the time is now for him to do the same Independent MP Ian Austin, who quit Labour over its ldquoculture of anti-Semitism in February, later told Mrs May he associated himself ldquocompletely with her ldquofine answer, adding: ldquoItrsquos absolutely clear to me that the vast majority of Labour MPs agree with her too.Mrs May last week made Mr Austin, the MP for Dudley North, a trade envoy to Israel.The comments about Mr Corbyn were a rare sour note in a PMQs in which MPs generally praised Mrs May for her commitment to public service -not her lasting achievements - and implicitly contrasted her dedication with her successorrsquos record and attitude.Mrs May was cheered as she entered a packed chamber shortly before noon, and drew attention to her husband Philip watching from the gallery."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "Theresa May pleased to hand over to Boris Johnson","description": "Theresa May pleased to hand over to Boris Johnson","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs QCxRGbCX-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests QCxRGbCX.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": After more than an hour fielding questions - a record for PMQs - her voice cracked as she said her duty now would be to serve her Maidenhead constituency from the backbenches.She said: ldquoThat duty to serve my constituents will remain my greatest motivation.As she left to make her way back to Downing Street, she received a standing ovation from Tory, LibDem and DUP MPs, while most of Labour and the SNP remained silent.The tone of the set-piece occasion was set by Labour MP Ruth Cadbury, who said she ldquoprofoundly disagreed with many of Mrs Mayrsquos decisions and policies, but recognised her ldquorespect for public service and for the future of our country.In the first of many swipes at Boris Johnson, Ms Cadbury continued: ldquoSo how does she feel about handing over to a man who, among many things, is happy to demonise Muslims, is prepared to chuck our loyal public servants and diplomats under a bus, and promises to sell our country out to Donald Trump and his friends Mrs May said she was ldquopleased to hand over to an incoming leader of the Conservative party and Prime Minister who I worked with when he was in my Cabinet, and who is committed, as a Conservative who stood on a Conservative manesto in , to delivering on the vote of the British people in  and to delivering a bright future for this country.Mr Corbyn praised Mrs Mayrsquos ldquosense of public duty.He said: ldquo I hope she has a marginally more relaxing time on the Back Benches. Perhaps, like the Chancellor, she will even help me oppose the reckless plans of her successor.When Tory MPs jeered, he added: ldquoI am glad the Government party is in such good heart today. Tomorrow it wonrsquot be.The Labour leader then highlighted increases in child poverty, violent crime, NHS waiting times, food bank use and school class sizes during Mrs Mayrsquos three years in office.ldquoDoes the Prime Minister have any regrets about any of those things Irsquove just said Mrs May said it was very good to see her party in good heart, adding: ldquoIt is more than I can say for the Labour Party.She went on: ldquoLet me just say something about my record over the past three years and how I measure it. It is in the opportunity for every child who is now in a better school. It is in the comfort for every person who now has a job for the first time in their le. It is in the hope of every disadvantaged young person now able to go to university. It is in the joy of every couple who can now move into their own home.ldquoAt its heart, politics is not about exchanges across the Dispatch Box. Nor is it about eloquent speeches or media headlines. Politics is about the dference we make every day to the lives of people up and down this country. They are our reason for being here, and we should never forget it.After Mr Corbyn askedshe thought Mr Johnson would succeed on Brexit where she had failed, she said she had worked ldquotirelessly for a good deal and to get it through Parliament, whereas Mr Corbyn had voted against it then walked away from talks.ldquoAt every stage, his only interest has been playing party politics, and frankly, he should be ashamed of himself, she said.SNP Westminster leader Ian Blackford said he had had his ldquodferences with Mrs May, adding: ldquoIt has not often been a shared meeting of minds.He said: ldquoHowever with the Prime Minister standing down today, the time for holding the Prime Minister to account has passed. The burdens of office are considerable, the loneliness of leadership can be stark. Whilst there are times we have clashed on points of political dference, equally we have stood together when it has been right to do so.He added: ldquoIs she confident that the office of Prime Minister can be upheld by her flagrant successor Mrs May praised her chief of staff Gavin Barwell before congratulating Mr Johnson.ldquoHe will take over as Prime Minister and I look forward to a first-class Conservative Government under his leadership, delivering for the whole of the United Kingdom.LibDem MP Tom Brake askedMrs May agreed politicians should ldquonever resort to, nor fail to call out, nationalistic rhetoric which demonised others, ldquobecausethey do, they are neither fit to be a President nor a Prime Minister Mrs May replied: ldquoIt behoves all of us as politicians - indeed, everyone in public le - to be careful about the language we use and to ensure that we give a clear a message that there is no place in our society for racism or hate crime.

title: theresa-may-legacy-torpedoed-brexit
story: She pledged to put ordinary, ldquojust managing families at its heart, and to fight burning injustices.ldquoIf yoursquore one of those families,yoursquore just managing, I want to address you directly, she said.ldquoI know yoursquore working around the clock, I know yoursquore doing your best, and I know that sometimes le can be a struggle.ldquoThe government I lead will be driven not by the interests of the privileged few, but by yours.It was stirring stuff."@context": "https:schema.org","@type": "VideoObject","name": "MPs give Theresa May standing ovation following final PMQs","description": "MPs give Theresa May standing ovation following final PMQs","thumbnailUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer thumbs MmRaO-.jpg","uploadDate": "--T::+:","duration": "PDTHMS","contentUrl": "https:cdn.jwplayer manests MmRaO.mu","embedUrl": "https:www.heraldscotland video  ","publisher": "@type": "Organization","name": "HeraldScotland","logo": "@type": "ImageObject","url": "https:www.heraldscotland sitelogo ","width": ,"height": But as Mrs May handed over the keys to Number  yesterday, it was clear her legacy will be defined by one thing and one thing only: Brexit.The UKrsquos failure to leave the EU has engulfed her time in office. Her attempts to force her Brexit deal through the House of Commons came to define her premiership.If she hoped to leave a legacy of tackling injustices, this was torpedoed by forces let loose following the  referendum.The daughter of a Church of England vicar, Mrs May was often hailed for her sense of duty and determination.After all, she survived three years of political chaos, at the head of a party riven with ision.But in the end, many believe her stubbornness and inflexibility simply made matters worse.Meaningless slogans such as ldquoBrexit means Brexit didnrsquot help, either.The humiliations came thick and fast, from s botched snap election to the infamous coughing fit at the Tory conference later that year.Earlier this month, Mrs May hailed the value of compromise in a speech on the state of politics.She said: ldquoToday an inability to combine principles with pragmatism and make a compromise when required seems to have driven our whole political discourse down the wrong path.ldquoIt has led to what is in effect a form of lsquoabsolutismrsquo ndash one which believes thatyou simply assert your view loud enough and long enough you will get your way in the end.For Mrs Mayrsquos critics, some of this might equally have applied to her doomed Brexit policy. Her deal was defeated three times before she gave up.In her resignation speech in May, the former prime minister attempted to focus on her achievements over the last three years.She listed successes such as reducing the deficit, bringing down national debt and calling an end to austerity.She also highlighted moves to protect the environment by ldquoeliminating plastic waste, tackling climate change and improving air quality.Mrs May insisted the "unique privilege of this office is to use this  to give a voice to the voiceless, to fight the burning injustices that still scar our society".She added: ldquoThat is why I put proper funding for mental health at the heart of our NHS long-term plan. It is why I am ending the postcode lottery for survivors of domestic abuse.ldquoIt is why the Race Disparity Audit and gender pay reporting are shining a light on inequality, so it has nowhere to hide."And that is why I set up the independent public inquiry into the tragedy at Grenfell Tower ndash to search for the truth, so nothing like it can ever happen again, and so the people who lost their lives that night are never forgotten.Perhaps history will be kinder to Mrs May than many of her colleagues.All the same, it must have stung a little when she saw the recent front cover of Private Eye.Publishing its ldquoTheresa May memorial issue at the beginning of June, the satirical magazine used its front page to list her legacy in full.It was blank.

title: commonwealth-games-voted-top-moment-scottish-tourism
story: Glasgowrsquos colourful and kitsch opening ceremony for the  Commonwealth Games five years ago this week kick-started  blistering hot days of sport and left its mark on a global audience who saw the city at its vibrant and colourful best.Now the huge sporting event ndash which brought around , visitors to Scotland as a direct result of the Games ndash has been voted the greatest moment in Scottish tourism.A poll created by tourism agency VisitScotland to mark its th anniversary today, has placed the Glasgow  Commonwealth Games as the biggest catalyst for bringing visitors to Scotland.The Games, which saw  athletes from  dferent nations and territories competing across  dferent sports, bagged  per cent of the votes and topped a string of events regarded as having a dramatic impact on tourist numbers.Included in the top five most important moments is the decision by Rough Guide readers to name Scotland as the most beautul country in the world.Scotland polled ahead of Canada and New Zealand in second and third places respectively, with lashings of praise for its ldquowild beaches, deep lochs and craggy castles and recommendation to tourists to visit Edinburghrsquos Old Town, Stirling Castle, Glen Coe and the beaches of South Harris.The Rough Guide listing ndash at a time when the exchange rate was already encouraging increasing numbers of American visitors - prompted tourism leaders at the time to predict an influx of extra tourists.The poll also highlights Scotlandrsquos leading role in blockbuster cinema and television dramas as helping to boost visitor numbers.The release of Braveheart in  was voted third most impactful event, taking % of the vote. The Mel Gibson epic sparked a surge in interest in Scotland and its history leading to a boost in visitor numbers for the National Wallace Monument in Stirling ndash leaping from , a year to nearly , in .The hugely popular Outlander book and later TV series are also regarded as key moments, along with the  Disney animation, Brave, which featured the voices of Billy Connolly, Robbie Coltrane and Kelly Macdonald.Large events which brought tourists flooding to Glasgow in particular also made the top , including the  Glasgow Garden Festival and Glasgowrsquos role as the City of Culture.Perhaps surprisingly, the top  of key moments does not include the opening of the Skye Bridge in , spanning Loch Alsh and connecting Kyle of Lochalsh with the island.The toll-free bridge is widely regarded as being key to the islandrsquos current tourism boom.However, it does include the launch of the Scottish Tourist Board in July  ndash voted fourth most signicant event for Scotlandrsquos tourism sector.And while rsquos high-profile and sometimes controversial Year of Homecoming polled % of the votes, there appears less enthusiasm for other heavily marketed lsquotheme yearsrsquo ndash such as the  Year of Creative Scotland or last yearrsquos Year of Young People.The introduction of themed years to Scotlandrsquos tourism landscape earned no votes at all.Some people taking part in the survey had their own ideas of what attracts people to Scotland.Among their suggestions was Andy Murrayrsquos Wimbledon win, the mere fact that Billy Connolly was born here, Nessie Sightings and, perhaps for the more niche tourist, ldquoHibs winning the Scottish FA Cup after  years.Meanwhile, opinions on what constitutes the most momentous event dfered across regions, with the Rough Guide status coming top among people in east central Scotland and the Highlands and Islands, while Braveheart took the honours in Aberdeen.Other key moments included the launch of the North Coast  route in  and the age of low-cost air travel, particularly the introduction of Easyjetrsquos Luton to Glasgow flights.However, it was the colourful and thrilling spectacle of the  Glasgow games which appears to have had most impact on showcasing the nation as a friendly and welcoming tourist destination.Scotland fielded its largest ever team at the  Games and won a record  medals in the process.Key moments included a rain-soaked final night of athletics which saw Usain Bolt dancing to sound of The Proclaimers and then joining fellow Jamaican runners in hats and scarfs as they celebrated their x metres relay celebrations, the Queen captured lsquophotobombingrsquo an Australian hockey players selfie, Motherwell boxing mailman Charlie Flynnrsquos biggest ever delivery ndash a gold medal ndash and a string of Scottish athleticsrsquo victories.Councillor David McDonald, Depute Leader of Glasgow City Council and Chair of Glasgow Le, said the Games had helped boost sport in the city: ldquoOur city has made some huge improvements in recent years which have created a real legacy from the Games.ldquoWersquore also set to host some spectacular events in the near future which would not have been possible had Glasgow not hosted and expertly delivered the  Commonwealth Games.Malcolm Roughead, Chief Executive of VisitScotland, said: ldquoOver the last  years there have been so many big moments for Scotlandrsquos tourism industry that it is dficult to choose just one, but the public has spoken.ldquoThe Glasgow  Commonwealth Games marked a momentous time for Scotland as we showed the world that we can host the biggest events on the planet and a global spotlight was shone on our country for visitors.ldquoAll of these moments and more have helped Scotland to become a tourism giant over five decades and while this is VisitScotlandrsquos own milestone, itrsquos very much an anniversary to be shared with our industry colleagues and partners.ldquoTodayrsquos success owes much to the vision of pioneers within this resilient and resourceful industry and our th allows us to look fondly at the past while, importantly, fixing our gaze toward the future.

title: herald-diary-gran-old-team
story: GREAT to see Irelands Shane Lowry out celebrating his Open Championship win by taking the famous Claret Jug with him to the pub ndash makes a change from American winners having one glass of Budweiser before getting on their private jet. We also liked his lovely old gran being interviewed on Irish television and recalling: "rsquoI remember his grandfather, after he won the Mulling Scratch Cup, saying: Get out there and bring me in a bucket of turf. He said: You wont see Tiger Woods bringing in turf. He thought he was Tiger Woods when he won the Mulling Scratch Cup! Ah great days."Put it thereTALKING of golf, an Ayrshire reader emails: "A woman here in Troon was taking her first golf lesson. She asked the instructor, I was just wondering, is the word spelled p-u-t or p-u-t-t  P-u-t-t is correct, he told her. P-u-t means to place something where you want it. P-u-t-t means merely a vain attempt to do the same thing."What planet you onWE ended our Moon landing stories, but a reader decides to remind us of the Moon night club on Sauchiehall Street ndash it was after my time as I knew it as the White Elephant. Anyway, although it has closed, you can still read reviews of it on Yelp where a woman named Adele left the memorable comment: "Worst nightclub around. The clientele was a sleazy mix of lecherous old men and mini-skirt-wearing minors, who seemed to be getting along famously. When I was approached and askedI had a boyfriend by a man older than my dad, I turned on my heel and left immediately."Any other Glasgow night club memories Waiting gameA READER declares: "My grandchildren love hearing stories of when I was growing up in the sixties ndash roller skates you had to tie on to your shoes, disappearing all day without your folks worrying, sweets from the penny tray. So I told them next time Im looking after them Ill treat them to a sixties experience. They dont know Ill go to the pub for a pint and leave them sitting outside with an Irn Bru and a packet of crisps."Getting a buzzSOME good weather around the last couple of days. A Knightswood reader tells us: "Have just let my neighbour know that Im going to sit outside and read for a while. Just to help him be on time with the hedge cutters."Dust-upSAW one of these pointless social media questions where someone asked: "If I were to break into your house and steal what is on top of your refrigerator, what am I getting " A Jerry Edwards from Glasgow merely replied: "Dust. Help yourself."Naming ceremonyGROWING old, continued. Can imagine a few folk will sympathise with writer and stand-up David Baddiel who revealed: "Sometimes when my memory fails me now with names, I just decide to say the name that my brain is suggesting to me as its best attempt, out loud. The other day whilst trying to tell my we something about artist Grayson Perry I said, Oh you know... Bunty Chudley.Ring to itTODAYS piece of whimsy comes from Victoria Sofia, who declares: "Fun date idea ndash put a fake diamond ring in your dessert and act like your date proposed. Men love that."Read more: : Rescue helicopter is star of the show at careers fair

title: letters-time-focus-debate-high-costs-independence
story: In my view it is testimony to the downright irresponsible coverage and shallow analysis of constitutional matters that none of these papers or politicians has pointed out that because of the tanking oil price the economics underpinning independence are far worse now than in  when oil was around  dollars a barrel today it is . Has anyone bothered to remind us that Scotland spends pound. billion more than it raises in taxes whilst the Scottish NHS costs around pound billion annually to run  No one has taken the time to tell us which taxes would increase and which welfare services would be cut and by how much to reduce this deficit.Again, in the rush to promote the break-up of the Union no one has bothered to discuss the minor irritant for Scots who have taken out their mortgages in sterling of the distinct possibility that their wages will be paid in a new Scottish currency which could be worth less than sterling. Do pensioners really want to take the risk of having their pensions paid in a new Scottish currency whilst the rest of the UK continue to receive theirs in sterling  It really is unbelievable that such important information is not even being discussed in this latest round of independence is just around the corner.The fact that independence is always discussed, stripped of its economic context, gives rise to the promotion of shallow but seductive tropes such as independence is the obvious alternative to a Johnson-led hard Brexit. But is it really  My hunch is that when people become aware of the turbo-charged austerity which would inevitably follow independence, that staying in the UK trumps a Johnson-led hard Brexit.Because of the appalling level of debate when it comes to constitutional issues the great worry is that the country could sleepwalk into independence. The crucial challenge for the majority who wish to remain in the UK is to recalibrate the independence debate to focus on the crucial economic consequences of independence that are never discussed: consequences such as how to pay off our fiscal deficit and our population shareof UK debt and how to find the pound billion to buy the currency reserves to fund a new currency to mention but a few.Robert Hoskins, Glasgow G.LIKE many who cannot accept our devolved power in Scotland and fancully believe all would be well with separation from the UK, Hugh Kerrseems to me to confuse personalities with policy.Having lived through  Prime ministers I can assure him that, to the public at least, politics is very often no more than a passing parade. Boris Johnson will come and go like the rest of them. If he attempts to behave presidentially he will doubtless meet the same fate as Margaret Thatcher.Although I personally feel that we have had to suffer the enervation imposed by the Tory Party elevating their court jester when our reserves were still depleted by Brexit, this is surely a time to keep the ship on an even keel.The ldquowake-up call advocated by Mr Kerr and targeted at the SNP is surely misdirected and as many would suggest, should be aimed at the Liberal Democrats. I consider that the Labour Party has, through self-inflicted errors of judgment, managed to make itself less likely to be elected into power than at any time since the Second World War.It is now for Jo Swinson, leader of the LibDems, to ldquodo a Boris and rally the troops while the Conservative party is still in conflict with itself. Not since  when Henry Campbell-Bannerman became Prime Minister for the Liberal Party has such an opportunity been presented.Bill Brown, Milngavie.CAST your mind back. The minute the result of the  Scottish independence referendum was announced, the SNP declared it was on the offensive. The minute the  Brexit referendum was announced, the SNP declared it was on the offensive. The minute Boris Johnsons premiership was announced, the SNP immediately declared itself on the offensive. All three events linked by the " necessity" for Scotland to go its own way.In these five years, Scotland has not done very well, but the important question is would it have been betterwe had split from England  The answer is resoundingly "no". The proof is the current state of Scotlands already-devolved powers and the numerous failures these have engendered. Saying that given all powers this would be so much better, is demonstrably wrong. The SNP is seeking any excuse to seize any half-chance to promote independence. That suggests desperation.Dr Gerald Edwards, Glasgow G.IF there was ever a crystal-clear indication of the pathetic state of the Labour Party in Scotland it is surely the comments by Labour councillor Alex Gallagher .On the day when the United Kingdom has had possibly the worst Prime Minister ever forced upon it by an extreme right-wing element within the Tory Party how does this representative of the Labour Party react  He writes a letter criticising the First Minister. You really could not make it up. If Mr Gallagher genuinely cared about this "United" Kingdom his thoughts and actions should have been directed towards ways to counteract the little Englander policies which Boris Johnson espouses.Not only does this show that Labour is in a deep hole but it also tells us that Mr Gallagher and his cohorts just cant stop digging.David Stubley, Prestwick.LIKE him or not, Boris Johnson has the same charismatic charm and panache as Alex Salmond used to have with the people and Scottish folk will soon warm to him as a politician with real character.He has a very dficult ahead taking the UK out of Europe but he is the one politician who has the capability to deliver to the people what they actually voted for.Dennis Forbes Grattan, Aberdeen AB.THE village joker has been anointed the saviour of the nasty party. A Titanic moment for the UK Ian Lennie, Falkirk.IS the world destined to be governed by self-serving, childish oafs, lacking in social skills or any degree of statesmanship, sporting dodgy haircuts and putting their personal ambition before what is best for their countries I, of course, refer to The Donald and to Kim Jong-un, and not to anyone at Westminster or Holyrood. The latter are, I am sure, working selflessly on our behalf.Brian Johnston, Torrance.

title: create-new-dementia-strategy-nicola-ll-sign
story: But Irsquom going to push all that aide. All you have to do is tackle dementia. Or rather the evil, iniquitous, le-sapping, pernicious, family-wrecking social policy in place whereby families have to sell their homes to pay for care.All you have to do is put an end to a system whereby dementia victims and their loved ones become victims of state policy.I sincerely hope there isnrsquot a dementia sufferer in your own family or friends group, butthere is yoursquoll be aware of the horror of watching someone close to you lose their memory by instalments, seeing their collection of precious moments that formed their le being deleted one by one, disappearing like Theresa Mayrsquos  promise to reform dementia policy, as though they had never happened.If there is yoursquoll empathise with the lung-choking, tear-flooding heartbreak that results when you realise the very essence of your loved onersquos personality is slipping away from them, the trauma that comes with trying to work out what is happening in that once-clever, creative mind in which thoughts are now bagatelling around.Yoursquoll have an understanding of how tragic the world becomes when a parent no longer recognises their own children, when an intelligent person with a wonderful lexicon canrsquot find the simplest word to explain what their feeling.Yoursquoll know how devastating it is to watch someone once of free spirit and fun and energy no longer able to make choices, to have preferences, to make the simplest decisions. Yoursquoll appreciate how dementia is about coping with a confusion and anxiety, which becomes a loud scream for help ndash and ends ultimately with deafening silence.You were once Health Secretary, but I donrsquot know how aware you are of the collateral damage of dementia ndash or of what you plan to do about it in an independent Scotland.Do you recognise that in order to have a solid, progressive ing society we need our people not only to lose their minds ndash research to find a cure has to be a priority ndash and families not to lose their dignity  They are being treated like the dirt-poor farmers in Steinbeck novels whose homes are repossessed by the bank.We need an end to a system whereby dementia is treated as ldquosocial cost illness, and those with more than pound, in the bank and a house have to pay for their own care home.UK Families have paid out pound. billion in the past two years alone. What sort of society have we created whereby a person who develops this illness of the brain is punished for being hard-working, careful and conscientious What of the NHS  Will it continue to pay for heart cancer operations for the obese, their ill-health often a result of a dereliction of personal responsibility, yet the dementia sufferer can have led a le of healthy control and see their legacy destroyed Not everyone has to watch their parentsrsquo home be sold to pay for care of course. The affluent can afford it, but most likely wonrsquot have to, because the home will have gone into a trust, which ring-fences assets.But for most the reality is tragedy, about learning to cope with money reserves dwindling and the familial friction which results from internal crises. And while time should be spent on making the dementia suffererrsquos experience as painless as possible, creating special moments, enjoying that le as much as is imaginable, what the relative doesnrsquot need is impending cash disaster, having to spend a single second worrying about selling a house to pay a pound, a week care home bill.Yes, the Scottish Government backs organisations such as Alzheimerrsquos Scotland, which provides important services to the community, putting training systems in place, creating dementia-aware shop facilities, drop-in centres. Itrsquos all good.But we need to make dementia, a disease that will destroy one in three, a primary focus. Michael Gove has spoken of the ldquoterrible shadow of dementia, promising to introduce ldquoa system of social care of insurance supported by the state, to prevent loss of homes.If he can do this canrsquot you  Hersquos right to recognise that dementia isnrsquot simply River Cityrsquos disease of the month. Itrsquos real. Itrsquos wrecking lives.In a bizarre sense, wersquore lucky in Scotland in that we donrsquot live as long as our counterparts in England. Yet, wersquore also working longer. Paying more National Insurance. For what But whatrsquos truly insane about mind loss is the way we classy it, that those who do live longer are being punished by having their legacy, often their very point of being, removed.End this now, Nicola. Come up with a plan to help the , present-day sufferers. And when you get the referendum you demanded yesterday Irsquoll sign on the dotted line.Read more: Scottish Government slammed over support given to dementia sufferers

title: revolutionary-concepts-add-new-spin-wind-turbine-design
story: Donald Trump famously threw a tantrum about them appearing off the coast near his golf course at Menie in Aberdeenshire. They have been accused of being noisy, intrusive, dangerous to wildle and a blot on the landscape.Onshore turbines are hugely important for energy generation they currently make up more than % of installed renewables capacity in Scotland.But Trump is not the only one to criticise the aesthetic impact of wind infrastructure .Other critics also consider that onshore developments compromise vistas across beautul countryside. They include Ramblers Scotland, which has claimed they are destroying Scotlandrsquos unique countryside and Mountaineering Scotland, which is also concerned that some developments are detrimentally affecting the mountain landscape.There is a strong counter argument that rows of slowly spinning turbines have a haunting, mesmeric beauty. If they are an art form to some, however, they are an overwhelmingly unorm one. Small wind farms, big wind farms, solo turbines ndash you see one, and yoursquove pretty much seen them all.This is not purely because of a lack of imagination to date in design. Current turbines, known as horizontal axis devices, are generally highly efficient in a way that is dficult to replicate in other configurations.However, they do have weaknesses, such as being able to capture wind in only one direction, so losing their efficiency when the flow becomes unpredictable.Two Lancaster University students, Nicolas Orellana and Yaseen Noorani, won the James Dyson Award last year for a radical new design called the O-Wind Turbine. It uses a cm spinning sphere sitting on a fixed axis and works with the wind blowing in any direction, making it particularly suitable for urban areas.Another even more unconventional potential solution is the Autonomous Tethered Aerostat an airborne wind turbine developed by the Boston-based company Altaeros Energies.This tethered blimp-like device looks like a giant tyre and floats in the air at a height of more than  metres. It provides a very dferent visual alternative to the traditional design, but its main benefit is that can harness the stronger winds found at altitude, also reducing ground noise and speeding up the investment payback period.Another advantage of the helium-filled AWT, which is assembled from the same material used for advanced racing sailing yachts, is that it is more visible to birds than the current horizontal axis turbines, which have been accused of being damaging to wildle.Other possibilities for the future include vertical axis turbines ndash originally conceived as a sail design by the ancient Persians ndash and bladeless inventions using spinning discs.There are also whale fin, helical shaped, windspire, windbelt, spiral drag and sky serpent designs, most looking as exotic as their names. But at present little has moved beyond, or even as far as, prototype stage.Dr Sergio Campobasso is a Senior Lecturer in Renewable Energy Engineering at Lancaster University and an authority on wind turbine design. He says that efficiency and aesthetics are competing issues: ldquoThere is a theoretical limit in terms of the energy that can be harvested from the wind, and the horizontal axis model is quite close to that.ldquoSome people do find that design boring. There are alternatives such as the vertical axis model, where the blades are parallel to the shaft, which may be considered more attractive. ldquoThe efficiency of these isnrsquot quite as high and there have been some issues with wind flow, but with progress in materials and better understanding of aerodynamics this design is being revisited.ldquoHowever, there isnrsquot nearly the same technological and financial support as is dedicated to the horizontal axis design. The biggest vertical axis being developed in the UK is  kilowatts, which is still in the small turbine range.Dr Campobasso says the sector is not lacking in imagination, with a team in Turkey working on a tower with oscillating wings aimed at mimicking the aerodynamics of the hummingbird ndash the only bird capable of hovering like a helicopter. But once again challenges with the wind dynamics and flow will have to be overcome. Tethered turbinesabove the ground also face issues.ldquoOne of these is upscaling, as the prototypes have been constructed at a relatively small scale. They may be fine for generating a few kilowatts, butwe are talking about wind farms with each turbine requiring to generate megawatts, then the route from that prototype is quite long.Another dficulty of this model is installing a weighty electrical generator on the floating turbine and then getting the power to the ground via a cable. ldquoThe Massachusetts Institute of Technologyis looking at this and potentially it is doable, but it requires investment. All this, he concedes, means that we are probably going to be looking at conventional and controversial horizontal rotors on onshore wind farms for at least another decade.ldquoHowever, potentially we will be able to develop turbines that present an interesting visual alternative to the existing ones. It will depend ultimately on the amount of resource industry and governments devote to this.The HeraldrsquosClimate for Changeinitiative supports efforts being made by the ScottishGovernmentwith key organisations and campaign partners.
